content:
Who is your mail provider? That is an essential when looking at delivery issues.

This is especially with some US based providers who appear incapable of understanding that they provide an SMTP service to submit emails to and have an obligation to support it when things go wrong. That is not any application support, it is support of their SMTP server being misconfigured or blacklisted for spam. Unfortunately the US pop up very frequently in SPAM discussions because their SPAM legislation is so poor that marketing they consider legitimate the rest of the world blocks as spam.

You can check the SMTP server against some of the blacklisting services. I personally find these folk to be fairly comprehensive https://www.spamhaus.org/

content:
Seems others have been reporting similar issues. Hope things are recoverable, or backed up.

Just a suggestion....

I'd back up if you can, then....

You may want to check your hard drive for problems. If it's an SSD, you there are other ways to check it...

There are a few things you can do, but to start, and what works may differ depending on what your main drive is called.

1. Open a Command Prompt as Admin. Type;

chkdsk /f /x /r

It will ask if it should run on your next start, enter "Y" and reboot. It will run for quite a while.

This will (F)ix the hard drive and also (R)epair or move what is in bad sectors, if possible.

2. In another Admin command prompt, type;

sfc /scannow

This is a System File Check, to be sure all Windows Files are OK.

There's more that can be done to check the drive, with free software even that will look for bad sectors, but that's a start. It will help rule out system problems such as Thunderbird or email stored in sectors that have gone bad, or just had an issue when storing them.

After that, search for "Thunderbird Repair" and see if any of what you find fits your issue.
creator: Chicks_Hate_Me

content:
There are a few reasons.

Things are case sensitive. Check the spelling and case or username, email, password, etc.

You could have an error in the settings as well for your email server or the Outgoing SMTP Server.

May need to check with the email provider to see what the correct settings are.

Also, with Google and others, you have to go to THIER site and Allow 3rd Party Software, or something like that so you can give access to Thunderbird. Otherwise you'll always be denied. Correct password or not.

Also, I've had to restart Thunderbird sometimes for things to take affect.

Good Luck!!!

content:
Do you have more than one account ? Is one set up as Pop and another set up as imap ? Or do you only have one account and it's not using the correct server settings for the type of account ?

In Account Settings In left pane select 'server settings' On the right at the top it says 'Server Type' Does it say Pop Mail Server or Imap Mail Server ? If Pop it must use Pop server settings If Imap it must use Imap server settings If you have two shaw accounts then you need two outgoing servers and each account must use it's own smtp server.

Also incoming and outgoing smtp the User Name - should be full email address not just 'ricc'. I would fix this first.

Any ideas, please?
creator: Tregarth

content:
Have you gone to Google - Security to see if the ability to use 3rd party apps is enabled for Thunderbird?

Mine worked for years, but recently it had issues. I had to go back into google security and Allow third-party apps again, specifically thunderbird, and then it started working again.

Google might be accepting mail for gmail via its SMTP servers, but not letting them go through to other email accounts. Just guessing....

Plus, in Thunderbird, there's two places for your password actually. One for your email server and another for the outbound via the SMTP server settings. Did you fix the SMTP password, but not the IMAP/POP one?

See if it's correct in SETTINGS-PRIVASCY & SECURITY - SAVED PASSWORDS.

You can even remove the one you think is a problem so it will ask again for it. Restart TB though first.

Might want to check there.

You could also do a search for "Thunderbird Repair" and you'll see a MOZ page with suggestions.

I also suggest being sure your system is up-to-date to rule that out, though unlikely the issue.

Back-up Do a chkdsk /f/r/x in an Admin Command Prompt. *Takes a while Do Windows Updates Do a sfc /scannow in an Admin Command Prompt. *Takes a while

creator: davidsk

content:
You may have right-clicked on the top of an email and UN-checked the Menu Bar AND the Composition Toolbar. With them BOTH gone, there's nothing at the top to click on to bring them back.

Luckily, they've made it so the Menu Bar will reappear simply by pressing the ALT Key, but once it shows you still need to right-click on it an reenable the Menu Bar so it will be visible in the future.

1. Click WRITE to open an email as if you were going to write one. 2. Press the ALT Key. Menu Bar should show 3. Right-Click on the same line as the Menu Bar and enable the Menu Bar again. 4. Right-Click on the same line as the Menu Bar and enable the Composition Toolbar again.

Hope this helps...

(See attached Profiles folder.) Do I have it in the right folder, and is the Profile Manager in my attached file the one I should be using?
creator: peterray

content:
I think you're confusing Thunderbird.

The folder is not the Profile. The profile is what is after the first "." Before the "." is a random name created by Thunderbird.

example: etcvhjf1.default = etcvhjf1 + "." + default (ONLY "default" is a profile name")

So you have 3 with the same Profile name "Default" and there should only be ONE of those, and you also have two "default-release" Profiles.

I'd probably move them ALL out (back them up) and start with one.

Create a Profile and then find THAT folder, and copy everything that is under your good stuff to under the NEW profile's folder. I haven't done that myself.

Also, Maybe Uncheck the "Use the selected profile without asking at startup" Box on ALL of them, until you decide the one you want to start up.

Or maybe just Create a NEW Profile and try to import from the the OLD profiles folder?
creator: Chicks_Hate_Me

content:
Your answer (above) helped me understand the issue, and it took a lot of trial and error, but I now see that when you said "Create a Profile and then find THAT folder, and copy everything that is under your good stuff to under the NEW profile's folder," you probably meant what I describe below:

(1) Create a new profile in profile manager, (2) make sure it will open, (3) delete all the files INSIDE that new profile, (4) compress the 30 GB of files in my old profile, (5) move them into the now empty new profile, and (6) decompress them. It was then possible to open this new profile, which now contains all the files from my old profile.

Thanks for your help!
creator: peterray

It was a little work but the NEW profile is clean and wicked fast, while I still have access to the OLD Profile. I could actually look at both at the same time....

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1415937#answer-1586887

Glad I could help. Take Care!!!

content:
If you have stopped receiving new messages and emails on your thunderbird account, the culprit is usually the firewall or the antivirus software. Open the interface for the antivirus or the firewall on your computer. Click on the menu and select Help. Then click on the button for Troubleshooting the Information

Regards, Will
